A beautiful house, with lovely furnishings, in a nice, quiet neighborhood. The host checked in with us before we got there, after we checked in, and before we left. We would highly recommend staying here.
Everything good
Very very nice place! Would definitely stay there again!

Wonderful. like a good relaxing dream came true. Peaceful.

Very nice and clean accommodations. Very peaceful on the farm and I would definitely like to come back again.

We loved the bunkhouse which is very roomy and well-equipped. After a couple of motel nights coming down from Canada, it was great to stretch our legs and walk around the ranch! There is a diner close by!
beautiful setting

The bunkhouse itself was comfortable and clean. There was a queen bed and two bunkbeds so it would accommodate a family nicely. The bunkhouse was equipped with a small refrigerator, microwave and a Keurig. That was more than enough to get us started and back on the road.
Highly recommend!
Thanks for a quiet night and a private, rural setting! Good coffee and Keurig, mini fridge, and Micro available. Thanks for being so warm and inviting in your communications!
Beautiful and very peaceful environment Thank you for having us.
Perfect space for our short trip to Rocky Mount. My wife and I enjoyed a warm sunny afternoon watching the horse lessons going on.

Gracie’s bunkhouse was a real treat to live the life in the country. As a city boy, I was a little out of place but enjoyed my stay. I envisioned myself in Yellowstone when we arrived and were glad we stayed!

great, quiet, place. Beautiful sight with animals.

lovely stay, we were very comfortable and relaxed.

Absouletly loved our stay at this bunkhouse! We only needed a place to shower and sleep for one night and Gracie's place met all our needs. The bedding was comfortable (very soft!) and cute especially the llama sheet set. There were plenty of towels readily available and small bottles of shampoo and soap to use. The bunkhouse does have a rustic appearance but it's very clean! All in all we have no real complaints and think most people would enjoy staying at this bunkhouse.

You can see the care put into every design choice from the thick marble kitchen counters to the salvaged building wood made into long rustic tables to the open shower and vessel tub in the bathroom. The decorating is so comfortable - deep, inviting sofas facing one another, a pillowy soft duvet on the bed, welcoming deep armchairs for reading, etc. Barbara recommended Varee nearby where we picked up delicious sushi to enjoy in the loft, then we walked two doors down to Tig's to grab breakfast & coffee in the morning. So worth a visit if you love historic, artistic spaces!

I couldn’t have been more charmed by the space, the host or the town! The Loft is fantastic — somehow even bigger and more beautiful than the pictures. Immaculately clean. My partner is six and a half feet tall and could still enjoy the rain shower (a rarity). I know this is probably irrelevant to the big picture, but the towels were made of the softest and nicest smelling fabric i’ve ever touched — such a luxurious touch. Barb is the perfect host; she adds those luxurious and delightful touches everywhere. She left us to our own after a quick & useful tour, but engaged when we initiated. Her recommendations for dining & activities were spot-on. The little town of Wilson has multiple art galleries within walking distance, and she pointed us to them all. Barb’s gallery (located downstairs) was the best, of course. But my favorite pieces of art were decorating the Loft.
You shouldn’t trust a review that only gushes, so I’ve tried hard to come up with a negative. All I can muster is that the blinds don’t fully block out light. Personally, i enjoy waking up with the sun and appreciate the amazing natural light. But if you want to sleep-in or take a day-nap in the dark, bring an eye mask. Also be aware (which Barb will remind you) that nearly every Downtown business is closed on Sundays. You’ll have to plan ahead with groceries, or be willing to drive 10 minutes to find an open restaurant.

I’ve stayed at countless Airbnbs and have had various experiences but never a nightmare like this! I realize she has good reviews so I don’t know what made my visit so different. If it was the sole fact of her being stressed out because of having a rodeo that night, then she needs to never rent out rooms during events since she was pissed off about having to be a host. But I’ll go chronologically.
Before arriving, she told me there would be a rodeo and if I wanted to attend, to go buy tickets online, which I did. What she didn’t tell me was that the rodeo would be right outside the cabin I would be staying at and I would be watching that rodeo and could watch it from the window whether I wanted to be or not. And could hear it from the speakers blastingly loud from inside the cabin. I say this because if I have been paying for peace and quiet on a farm, I wouldn’t have gotten it, so I don’t think it was fair I had to pay for the rodeo tickets and she should have been upfront about that. I was also not allowed to park near the cabin because the vendors were parked there so I had to park in a huge field and walk far away to get to the cabin. She should have also given me a heads up that would be the situation. Since my journey was part of me moving since I got a new job that needed me to re-locate immediately, I didn’t have an easy overnight bag and I had planned on just grabbing items loosely from the vehicle. And then the fact that it was pouring down rain made going back & forth that far away to the car even more miserable.
There was no key to the cabin and I was worried about leaving my stuff unattended inside with hundreds of people walking around. Her listing had sounded very friendly about calling or texting her or her husband for anything I needed, so I called her just to ask about the key and she acted very frustrated and annoyed and gave me instructions as to where to find one. Well, the key didn’t work. I even recorded a video of me using this key in every direction on both locks on that door to prove it didn’t work. I sent her one simple nice text letting her know the key didn’t work and she never responded.
Since I didn’t want to leave with our stuff in there and I didn’t want to go through the rain to go back to the car to look for something to entertain my six year old with, I started looking around the place. Tons of dead flies on the windowsills. More than could have died and just that one day. But that’s fine. I can deal with that. But then I noticed the lamp on the nightstand had a funnel spider on it near the top where you would need to put your hand. A LIVE funnel spider. I am arachnophobic! I then started to worry and inspect things further. I peeled back the sheets and there were dead bugs and grass in them! The towels were in this little basket and there were dead bugs, hair, and dirt inside the fabric of that basket that could’ve easily been cleaned. maybe 30 minutes had gone by since my last text so I sent another with the pictures, such as of the funnel spider, and told her I was disappointed with finding the bugs in the sheets but that the funnel spider was too much and could somebody please come at least get rid of the spider. Still no response.
The rain started to let up and then there was pounding on the door that was so loud and aggressive both my kid and I jumped and I was scared to answer the door. I honestly pictured there being three angry men outside the door but the pounding wouldn’t stop so I swung the door open from far away and it was her just beating repeatedly on the door as fast as she could with both fists. She immediately started SCREAMING at us at the top of her lungs—like full of utter RAGE! “HOW DARE YOU CONTACT ME DURING AN EVENT! GET OFF MY PROPERTY! I’M CALLING THE POLICE!” My son starts crying and wailing, grabbing stuff off the bed to try to run away from her, telling me to run because she’s going to kill us—-that’s the level of terror she inspired. I was shaking & asked her to please calm down and communicate with me civilly and that she was terrifying my son. “OBVIOUSLY YOU’VE NEVER STAYED ON A FARM! LEAVE NOW!!!! GET OUT!!!!!! THE POLICE ARE COMING!!!” My 6 year old starts screaming that we’re going to jail. She stomps away backwards, screaming and repeating the same things to get off her property and the police are coming, waving her fists around at us.
I reported that I didn’t feel safe to Airbnb support and then called them and they told me not to leave yet. I tried to tell them how scared my son was and I had no idea what the protocol was in a situation like this nor did I know if we’d find anywhere else to stay this late (maybe 8pm by then?). They transferred me to someone else, who also told me not to leave yet and then eventually they said I could go ahead and go and just send them pictures. Unfortunately, their message wouldn’t let me send any of the videos I took.
For the record, my grandparents had a farm (my Dad lives there now) and I have actually LIVED on a farm! But living on a farm doesn’t mean you want to get bit by a spider on your nightstand lamp! Or that you don’t desire
